beloved_daniel wrote:

>  > My guess is that you did not write
>  >     bool assertEquals(Object other)
>  > but
>  >     bool assertEquals(MyClass other)
>  > Then in assertTrue(object1.equals(object2)) your method is called.
>  > To fit the assertEquals argument list, the arguments get converted
>  > to Object, and the original Object.equals(Object) is called.
> 
> Great hint :-) - thank you so much! Now it works.
> I'm not only new in JUnit but also new in Java ;-).

Which IDE do you use? In Eclipse, a method is marked with a little arrow 
indicating "I override a method up there". In this case, not seeing the 
little arrow could have been your clue that you weren't overriding the 
method that you thought you were overriding.

Take care.
--
